title: A NEW AMPHIBAMID (TEMNOSPONDYLI: DISSOROPHOIDEA) FROM THE EARLY PERMIAN OF TEXAS

affiliation.institution: University of Paris VI (Pierre et Marie Curie)

abstract: The Amphibamidae are undergoing intensive investigation at present, with many new species recently described to better understand their interrelationships and role in the origin of extant amphibians. A new genus and species of amphibamid, Rubeostratilia texensis, represented by a skull from the Early Permian of Texas, shows many similarities with a recent described species from Richards Spur, Oklahoma, Pasawioops mayi. The skull is elongate and oval, with enlarged external naris and orbits, typical of the other amphibamids within the Micropholis-Tersomius cluster. The skull exhibits the laterally exposed palatine (LEP) and the dorsal quadrate process typical of the Dissorophoidea. Unlike Pasawioops, the new species preserves only a few additional characters relevant to amphibamid relationships: the pterygoid contacts only the ectopterygoid, the postfrontal's shape is falciform, and the alary processes do not extend further posteriorly than one-half of the length of the external naris. We included Rubeostratilia in a recently published amphibamid matrix, to which we added four characters, and conducted two separate phylogenetic analyses, differing in the coding of three characters in the genus Plemmyradytes. The results demonstrate the importance of precision in coding for each character, because these minor changes lead to two different topologies. A brief morphometric analysis of amphibamid cranial anatomy was conducted to better understand the nature of the different morphotypes among which the new species clusters. The results of both morphometric and phylogenetic analysis add support to the emerging consensus that amphibamids cluster into two distinct clades.

abstract.text: The Amphibamidae are undergoing intensive investigation at present, with many new species recently described to better understand their interrelationships and role in the origin of extant amphibians. A new genus and species of amphibamid, Rubeostratilia texensis, represented by a skull from the Early Permian of Texas, shows many similarities with a recent described species from Richards Spur, Oklahoma, Pasawioops mayi. The skull is elongate and oval, with enlarged external naris and orbits, typical of the other amphibamids within the Micropholis-Tersomius cluster. The skull exhibits the laterally exposed palatine (LEP) and the dorsal quadrate process typical of the Dissorophoidea. Unlike Pasawioops, the new species preserves only a few additional characters relevant to amphibamid relationships: the pterygoid contacts only the ectopterygoid, the postfrontal's shape is falciform, and the alary processes do not extend further posteriorly than one-half of the length of the external naris. We included Rubeostratilia in a recently published amphibamid matrix, to which we added four characters, and conducted two separate phylogenetic analyses, differing in the coding of three characters in the genus Plemmyradytes. The results demonstrate the importance of precision in coding for each character, because these minor changes lead to two different topologies. A brief morphometric analysis of amphibamid cranial anatomy was conducted to better understand the nature of the different morphotypes among which the new species clusters. The results of both morphometric and phylogenetic analysis add support to the emerging consensus that amphibamids cluster into two distinct clades.

body_text.text: The Amphibamidae have been the subject of much recent research due to their pivotal role in the ancestry of some, or all, of the living amphibians (Lissamphibia: frogs, salamanders, and caecilians; see Milner, 2004, and Anderson, 2008 , for recent reviews). After a flurry of recent work, we recognize 10 genera among this group: Doleserpeton (Bolt, 1968 (Bolt, , 1969 , Amphibamus (Cope, 1865; Bolt, 1979; Milner, 1982) , Tersomius (Romer, 1947; Carroll, 1964) , Micropholis (Huxley, 1859; Boy, 1985; Schoch and Rubidge, 2005) , Eoscopus (Daly, 1994) , Plemmyradytes (Huttenlocker et al., 2007) , Platyrhinops (Romer, 1947; Carroll, 1964; Milner, 1993, 2010) , Pasawioops (Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) , Georgenthalia (Anderson et al., 2008a) , and Gerobatrachus (Anderson et al., 2008b) .

As each species has been described or revised, it has been added to a growing character by taxon matrix initiated by Schoch and Rubidge (2005) , and the result of these phylogenetic analyses is an emerging consensus of internal amphibamid relationships: a "Micropholis" and an "Amphibamus" clade with varying composition (Huttenlocker et al., 2007; Anderson et al., 2008a; Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) . For example, when Huttenlocker et al. (2007) established the new species Plemmyradytes, they supported the idea of grouping Plemmyradytes with Micropholis, Eoscopus, and Tersomius; this group separated from Doleserpeton, Amphibamus, and Platyrhinops. Independently, Anderson et al. (2008a) included the new species Georgenthalia to their modified version of the Schoch and Rubidge (2005) matrix and similarly supported the idea of grouping Micropholis and Tersomius together. Fröbisch and Reisz (2008) combined both of these previous analyses with their own modifications, and their result supported the idea of grouping Pasawioops with Micropholis and Tersomius, and Doleserpeton, Amphibamus, and Platyrhinops with Eoscopus and Plemmyradytes.

cite_spans.text: Amphibamus, and Platyrhinops. Independently, Anderson et al. (2008a)

body_text.text: Here we describe a new genus of amphibamid from Texas. We explore its relationships in greater detail by adding it to the growing amphibamid matrix, which we modify by adding a new character. The data are further explored for the effects of incomplete character coding and wild card behavior among some species. Finally, a landmark-based morphometric analysis is performed on amphibamids for the first time.
Institutional Abbreviations-FMNH, Field Museum of Natural History, Chicago; TMM, Texas Memorial Museum, Austin.

Anatomical Abbreviations-a, angular; ch, choana; co, coronoid; cp, cultriform process of parasphenoid; d, dentary; ect, ectopterygoid; f, frontal; imf, intermeckelian fenestra; inf, internarial fenestra; j, jugal; l, lacrimal; lj, lower jaw; LEP, lateral exposure of palatine; n, nasal; m, maxilla; p, parietal; pa, prearticular; paf, parietal foramen; pal, palatine; pm, premaxilla; po, postorbital; pof, postfrontal; pos, postsplenial; pp, postparietal; ppb, palpebral cup elements; prf, prefrontal; ps, parasphenoid; pt, pterygoid; q, quadrate; qj, quadratojugal; sa, surangular; sm, septomaxilla; sp, splenial; sq, squamosal; st, supratemporal; t, tabular; v, vomer; vd, vomerine depression. TEMNOSPONDYLI Zittel, 1888 DISSOROPHOIDEA Bolt, 1969 AMPHIBAMIDAE Moodie, 1909 RUBEOSTRATILIA, gen. nov.
Etymology-Generic name Rubeostratilia derived from the Latin translation of 'Redbeds' (rubeo, ruber, rubrus = red; stratum, strati = bed) where the specimen was found in Texas.
Diagnosis-As for species.
RUBEOSTRATILIA TEXENSIS, Holotype-FMNH PR1460. Flattened skull with the left side partially, but the right side well, preserved. A portion of the mandible is preserved.
Etymology-Specific epithet in honor of Texas where the specimen was found.

Horizon and Locality-The specimen was found east of Henrietta in Clay County, Texas, in 1941 by a Work Projects Administration (WPA)-sponsored fossil-collecting project in the Wichita Group, Nocona Formation, Early Permian (Asselian-Sakmarian). The locality is identified as TMM 31226; specific information is on file at the Texas Memorial Museum in Austin. The specimen was obtained by the Field Museum through an interinstitutional exchange with the Texas Memorial Museum.

Diagnosis-Amphibamid temnospondyl uniquely with pterygoid suture exclusive with ectopterygoid, and four equally sized foramina in a row in the lacrimal that forms the anterior wall of the orbit. Shares with Pasawioops: skull longer than wide, and the same pattern of ornamentation on the bones. It differs from Pasawioops by: vomer with shagreen of teeth and fang pair in Rubeostratilia but only at juvenile stages or absent for Pasawioops; prefrontal process contacting lacrimal for Rubeostratilia but lacrimal and palatine for Pasawioops; and alary processes longer for Pasawioops. Shares with other amphibamids: palatine and ectopterygoid narrow struts not wider than adjoining maxilla. Shares with other dissorophoids: presence of lateral exposure of the palatine; lack of lateral contact between jugal and lacrimal; presence of posteromedial process of the quadratojugal; dorsal quadrate process; vomerine dentition consisting of large fang pair rostral to the choana and two additional fang pairs lateral and rostromedial to the choana; and presence of palpebral ossifications.

The skull is dorsoventrally compressed. The left side in dorsal view (Fig. 1A, B ) is almost completely absent but the right side is well preserved. Crushing has disarticulated most of the bones and has damaged many of them. For instance, most of the supratemporal is present, but the edges are not very well preserved, being either overlain by other bones or matrix, or were broken off during the process of fossilization. Bones situated on the edge of the skull suffered the most damage. Little anatomical information is preserved on the lower jaw. The right mandible is missing all but the dorsomedial bones in its anterior half, and the lateral surface of the posterior half is completely uninterpretable. The left anterior half of the mandible has been seriously damaged by grinding, and the posterior half is mostly unprepared. Nevertheless, we can still see in places well-preserved parts of the skull with bones still in articulation, such as the lacrimal, which is damaged on the anteriolateral border but is still articulated with the prefrontal.

The skull is elongate and ovoid, with enlarged external nares and orbits (Fig. 1C) , typical for basal amphibamids such as Tersomius. The orbits of this specimen are relatively large, longer than wide. Compared with the size of the skull, the proportion of the orbits (Anderson et al., 2008a) are similar to Amphibamus, Doleserpeton, and Georgenthalia, with a ratio around 0.35-0.40, whereas the remaining amphibamids have ratios in the range of 0.35-0.25. Additionally, small osseous elements are preserved in the dorsal half of the right orbit, originally associated with the palpebral cup. All the dorsal bones show a light ridge and groove pattern of dermal sculpturing on their superficial surfaces, which is not common among dissorophoids except amphibamids.

The nasal is very well preserved and shows clearly the deeply interdigitating margins of the internasal suture ( Fig. 1 ). It is a broad, trapezoidal bone that represents a major part of the rostral portion of the skull roof and forms the posteromedial margin of external naris. The nasal has a recess that receives the alary process of the premaxilla on its rostrolateral margin, paralleling the dorsal margin of the external naris. The nasal meets the lacrimal and the prefrontal laterally and has a strongly interdigitating suture with the frontal.

The frontal is an elongate bone that forms the dorsal margin of the orbit. It meets the nasal rostrally, the prefrontal rostrolaterally, the postfrontal posterolaterally, and the parietal posteriorly with a deeply interdigitating suture. Its lateral margin flares laterally at its rostral end. Its total length is about equal to the rostroposterior extent of the orbit.

The parietal is the best-preserved bone of this skull. A large part of the left parietal is shown in near articulation with the right in dorsal view, permitting easy delineation of the position and relationships of the parietals. It articulates with the frontal rostrally with a deeply incised suture; the right parietal has two rostral processes, and the left a single one that extends rostrally near the midpoint of the lateral length of the suture between the left frontal and parietal. The parietal contacts the postfrontal anterolaterally, which causes a rostral constriction in the lateral margin of the parietal. There are additional articulations with the supratemporal posterolaterally, along a relatively simple suture, and the postparietal posteriorly with an interdigitating suture. Posterior to the parietal foramen, the interparietal suture becomes very deeply interdigitating; just posterior to the foramen, the suture takes a major excursion left of the midline, with smaller interdigitations along its length, and then further posteriorly it takes a similar right excursion that has fewer minor interdigitations, before returning to follow approximately the midline.

The supratemporal, a long, rectangular bone with nearly the same length as the parietal, represents a major portion of the posterior skull roof. This supratemporal makes contact with the postfrontal rostromedially and the postorbital rostrolaterally. There is a long and straight medial suture with the parietal. The supratemporal contacts the squamosal and forms the lateral margin of the otic notch, but breakage in this area makes the identification of a supratympanic or semilunate flange impossible. It makes a contact with the postparietal posterolaterally and the tabular posteriorly at a relatively deeply interdigitating suture.

Unlike the other bones of the skull roof, the postparietal is short. It has its greatest rostroposterior extent at the midline and then becomes shorter, tapering laterally approximately twothirds of the width of the occipital surface of the skull and terminating at a point articulation with the medial edge of the tabular. The occipital flange of the postparietal is exposed in dorsal view because of rostral rotation of the right element; it is smooth (unornamented), and extends more ventrally on its lateral margin, framing much of the dorsal foramen magnum. At the midline, the dorsal occipital margin is framed by a robust transverse bar, presumably for insertion of epaxial musculature of the neck. It makes a deeply interdigitating suture with the parietal and contacts the supratemporal rostrolaterally.

Like the postparietal, the tabular is also rostroventrally rotated to show the occipital surface in dorsal view. A tabular 'horn' is present on its posterolateral margin. The tabular is transversely a very narrow bone, except at the 'horn,' and makes contacts with the postparietal along a short, but deeply interdigitating suture.
The lateral edge forms the posteromedial part of the roof of the otic notch.

Just a very narrow part of the premaxilla is well preserved (Figs. 1, 2 ). It clearly shows an alary process (Sequeira and Milner, 1993) , widespread among temnospondyls, which overlapped the nasal dorsal to the external naris. A dental (maxillary) ramus forms the rostroventral border of the external naris, but we cannot determine a tooth count.

The septomaxilla is well ossified and exposed in the right external naris in the dorsal view. It is a very small and smooth bone. Not normally seen in dorsal view in temnospondyls, the septomaxilla is situated inside the naris, partially under the nasal, and forms the internal medioventral wall of the external naris.

A very narrow part of the maxilla is exposed in dorsal view, from near the jugal to the posterior part of the lacrimal. The maxilla is a slender, elongate element, along the ventrolateral side of the skull. It forms the ventral margin of the external naris and extends to the cheek region of the posterior rim of the orbit. The maxilla makes contact with the lacrimal and the lateral exposure of palatine (LEP) laterally and the jugal posteriorly. Along the suture with the jugal the facial ramus increases in height, reaching an apex just below the rostral margin of the orbit, rapidly decreases in height below the orbit, and then gradually tapers posteriorly until it is too damaged to trace further. Teeth are not present along the entire row but from the alveoli it is estimated to have had space for between 45 and 55 teeth.

Between the lacrimal and the jugal, an expansion of the palatine bone, called the lateral exposure of the palatine (LEP; Bolt, 1969) , is shown on the dorsal view (Fig. 1) . The LEP is short, and forms part of the ventrolateral rim of the orbit, preventing the maxilla from participating in the orbital margin. It makes contact with the lacrimal rostrally, with the jugal posteriorly, and with the maxilla ventrally.

The lacrimal is an elongate, triangular bone, which forms the posterior border of the external naris and the rostrolateral rim of the orbit. It contacts the LEP posterolaterally. There is a suture with the prefrontal posteromedially and the nasal rostromedially. The lacrimal has four foramina within the rostral orbital wall arranged in a linear, ventral to dorsal, manner. Presumably these are related to the nasolacrimal canal, the passage of branches of the trigeminal nerve, and associated vasculature; however, one of the ventral-most foramina appears to hook right and be exit through a foramen on the lateral wall of the lacrimal. Unfortunately, computed tomographic (CT) scans were unsuccessful in imaging this area of the skull and directly observe the passage of these canals because of the radio opacity of the matrix. Doleserpeton was also described as having '3 to 5' foramina on the anterior orbital wall of the lacrimal (Bolt, 1968) . As figured ( fig.  15a ; Bolt, 1968) , however, it appears that only three are arranged linearly, with a smaller fourth off the main axis of the other three (a fifth does not appear in the figure) .

The prefrontal is a triangular bone, which forms the dorsorostral rim of the orbit. It makes an interdigitating suture with the lacrimal rostrolaterally. The rostral tip contacts the nasal. There is a posterior process that contacts the frontal medially, but makes no contact with the postfrontal. The prefrontal and the lacrimal are tightly integrated. The suture between the nasal and the prefrontal is not clear because the nasal overlaps the prefrontal, but the margin of the nasal shows a number of projections indicating an interdigitating suture. The frontal also covers the posteromedial edge of the prefrontal.

The postfrontal is a well-preserved bone; only the lateral edge is broken. The postfrontal has a slender rostral process that contacts the frontal and forms the posterodorsal part of the orbit. Medially, there is a suture with the parietal. The postfrontal meets the postorbital on lateral side and the supratemporal posteriorly.

The triangular postorbital is a well-preserved bone, and is still in articulation with the jugal. All the edges are present, although they appear to be slightly worn and rounded posteriorly. It forms the posterior orbital margin, the rim of which is slightly raised. The apex of the triangle points posteriorly, lying between the supratemporal and the squamosal. A slender rostrodorsal process runs along the orbital rim, the dorsal-most portion of which is below the level of the palpebral elements. The postorbital contacts the postfrontal medially and the jugal ventrally.

The jugal is narrow rostrally and forms a slender posteroventral rim of the orbit. It contacts the LEP along a small suture at its very rostral tip, and dorsally it articulates with the postorbital with a broad underlapping suture. Posteriorly, there is a contact with the postorbital and the squamosal. There is a very narrow posteroventral suture with the quadratojugal.

The quadratojugal makes contact with the posterior end of the jugal and forms a very long suture medially with the squamosal. It follows the curvature of the otic notch, where it forms the posteroventral corner of the notch, with a smooth flange that passes medially visible in the notch in dorsal view, as seen in other amphibamids like Georgenthalia (Anderson et al., 2008a) and Eoscopus (Daly, 1994) .

The squamosal, the largest bone of the cheek, comprises two portions: a sculptured trapezoidal portion with an anterior triangular process wedged between the postorbital and jugal that presumably adhered closely with the dermis, and a medially sloping smooth part, forming the majority of the interior of the large otic notch posteriorly. There is no sutural contact with the tabular. The squamosal embayment forms the otic notch. It is a threedimensional structure, although not very well preserved in this specimen; the presence of a semilunate or supratemporal flange cannot be determined.

The palate, formed by the vomers, palatines, ectopterygoids, and pterygoids, is partially preserved (Figs. 2, 3 ). All of the right palate is visible in ventral view, but the left is mostly obscured by a medioventral folding of the lower jaw and side of the skull.

The vomer forms the rostral-most part of the palate and the two-thirds of the rostromedial border of the elongate choana. There is a deep intervomerine depression (Fig. 3 ) in the rostral region but no intervomerine foramen is detectable. Three pairs of vomerine fang-(sensu Bolt and Lombard, 2001 ) pit pairs are present: one near the midpoint of the medial margin of the choana near the suture with the palatine, one on the ridge that forms the lateral margin of the intervomerine depression near the midpoint of the vomer, and a third at the rostromedial margin of the choana (its fang is shown in section in Fig. 3 ). Rows of small, recurved denticles radiate outward from a focal point near the fang-pit pair at the rostromedial margin of the choana. The vomer is in contact with the palatine posterolaterally at an oblong suture along the posterior margin of the choana.

The palatine is very well preserved. It is a long, slender bone extending longitudinally along the interpterygoid vacuity. With the vomer, its rostral medial process forms the posteromedial border of the choana. It contacts the ectopterygoid posteriorly. The palatine has a dorsal process visible in lateral view (LEP) suborbitally. The LEP has a suture with the lacrimal rostrally and jugal posteriorly. There is one fang situated close to the choana and a second along the suture line with the maxilla.

The full posterior extent of the ectopterygoid is obscured by the overlying pterygoid and matrix. It has a small transverse crest in the middle that shows the force of the downward crushing that split it in two. The ectopterygoid is in contact with the palatine rostrally along a roughly anterolateral to posteromedial transverse suture that restricts the posterior palatine from exposure in the interpterygoid vacuity. It appears to articulate solely with the pterygoid posteriorly, although the exact nature of the articulation is obscured by disarticulation and overlying matrix. There are no evident facets for articulation with the medial magin of the palatine so it appears the pterygoid articulated solely with the ectopterygoid. The entire ventral surface of the ectopterygoid is covered with a shagreen of denticles; no fang-pit pairs are evident.

Despite post mortem deformation, the right pterygoid kept its three-dimensional form, although it is slightly rotated out of position. Only a little of the left pterygoid is visible, because it is overlain by the right lower jaw. The pterygoid is a prominent, tri-radiate bone, formed by palatine, basipterygoid, and quadrate processes. The palatine process is in contact with the ectopterygoid rostrally and is covered with a shagreen of denticles. It is slightly displaced from its natural position of articulation, but this is deemed to be exclusively on the ectopterygoid for a number of reasons. First, the anterior-most tip of the pterygoid is complete and finished with smooth bone, and did not extend further. Second, there is no evidence for an articulation facet along the medial surface of the palatine. Third, the upward force applied by the pterygoid on the posterior ectopterygoid could have produced the transverse crack, which runs posterior to the slightly more oblique suture between the ectopterygoid and palatine. The basipterygoid ramus, comprised of a rostral and posterior lamina forming a dorsally oriented chevron, forms a loose basicranial articulation with the parasphenoid, which fits into the ventral space of basipterygoid articulation with a laterally directed peg. There is a lateral flange that projects into the subtemporal fenestra along the lateral surface of the junction between the palatine and quadrate processes opposite the basipterygoid process.

The quadrate is only partially preserved on the right side and can be seen only in lateral view. As in all dissorophids, it makes an articulation with the lower jaw and has a dorsal process. The quadrate meets the quadratojugal laterally and the squamosal rostrally and makes a contact with the quadrate ramus of pterygoid ventrolaterally.

A large portion of the occiput is formed by the postparietals and tabulars (see above) ( Fig. 1) . The postparietal seems to form the dorsal portion of the foramen magnum; unlike described for Dissorophus (Carroll, 1964) and Kamacops (Schoch, 1999) , there is no supraoccipital (see Maddin et al., 2010 for a more extended discussion). Additional bones are present on the right occipital surface (Fig. 1 ). One has a narrow, but thick, base near the lower margin of the foramen magnum, and thins as it fans out dorsolaterally to articulate with the skull roof near the suture between the tabular and postparietal. It is difficult to determine, but it appears to underlap the tabular at least at this point. This is interpreted as being the paroccipital process of the opisthotic. Near the base of the paroccipital process, rotated out of position to the right of its natural position, is a portion of what is probably the opisthotic. On its dorsorostral surface the posterior margin of the fenestra ovalis can be seen. Extending dorsomedially from this point, below the base of the paroccipital process, is a portion of the exoccipital, which would have formed the lateral margin of the foramen magnum, although no sutures are visible to distinguish between it and the opisthotic. Near the stem of the paroccipital process, a small foramen can be seen on the occipital ramus of the postparietal. Based on location, this could be the jugular foramen; however, it is smaller in size than that in amphibamids, so it could be a nutrient foramen. If it is the jugular foramen, it implies that the occipital ramus of the postparietal has fused with the exoccipital, of which no trace can be seen in the specimen.

Most of the parasphenoid is well preserved except for the basal plate ( Fig. 2) . It is also covered by two hyobranchial elements, possibly ceratobranchials or ceratohyals, as seen in Pasawioops. The parasphenoid basal plate bears prominent lateral processes that form the basicranial articulation together with the basicranial processes of the pterygoids in a peg and socket articulation. The basal plate is too damaged to establish its shape. It is completely covered by numerous denticles, which extend onto at least the base of the cultriform process; the full extent of the denticulated cultriform process cannot be determined because of overlying osseous plates, as seen in Pasawioops (Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) .

As in other dissorophoids, a portion of a short, robust sphenethmoid is preserved interorbitally. It comprises paired flanges of bone that have a triangular cross-section due to the ventral articulation with the cultriform process and the dorsolateral flaring to the articulation with the underside of the frontals. It cannot be directly determined whether the sphenethmoid is as tightly integrated with the frontals as seen in other dissorophoids (e.g., Cacops; Reisz et al., 2009) , but indirectly this seems to be the case, as determined by the resistance to dorsoventral compression the sphenethmoid has provided.
Other than the opisthotic (described above), no other braincase elements are visible, including the stapes.

Very little of the dentary is preserved; what is determinable is restricted to the posterior part of the jaw except where preparation damage has caused a portion of it to be exposed in longitudinal section anteriorly (Figs. 4, 5) . The splenial, or possibly the splenial and postsplenial-breakage makes it difficult to determine-represents two-thirds of the rostroventral lower jaw with a narrow labial and broad lingual exposure. The splenial appears to participate in the symphysis.

The entire coronoid region is preserved in ventrolingual view. The sutures between the presumed three elements cannot be distinguished from breakage, and any possible coronoid process is obscured by the overlapping pterygoid. The coronoids bear a large number of denticles in an irregular pattern.

The deeply sculptured angular forms the ventral and lateral sides of the posterior jaw ramus, as seen on the left jaw in lateral view. There is a slender rostral process of the prearticular that wedges between the coronoid dorsally and the possible postsplenial ventrally in lingual view on the right jaw.

There are two hyoid elements lying en chevron across the basal plate of the parasphenoid, with their apex located at the base of the cultriform process and extending posterolaterally toward the occiput (Fig. 2) . Each element is broken in multiple places. They measure approximately 7.75 mm (anatomical left) and 8.55 mm (right) long (actual length as preserved). Like the similar elements described in Platyrhinops by Clack and Milner (2010) , they are flattened and have a longitudinal groove running their length, but unlike those in Platyrhinops they are located posteriorly, which suggests that the elements, which are only present unilaterally in the two specimens of Platyrhinops that preserve them, are displaced rostrally. Similar, although relatively shorter, elements have also been described in Pasawiops (Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) in the same location as we describe for Rubeostratilia. We agree with the interpretation of Clack and Milner (2010) that these are most likely ceratohyals, used for anchoring tongue musculature.

The skull reconstruction was made from the right side and extrapolated to the largely unpreserved left side assuming bilateral symmetry, although the midline sutures were taken from the specimen (Figs. 1C, 2C ). The profile of the lower jaw constrains the shape of the skull. The outline was reconstructed using other amphibamids as a guide, and using the distance between the two otic notches (postorbital skull table) and the conformation of the otic notch itself. To correct for bone breakage and displacement, each bone (or partial bone) was drawn individually and the skull was thus reassembled using a light box. For instance, the right vomer is very well preserved whereas we can see just one-third of the left. A very little piece of the two vomers at the bottom was broken off by the cultriform process of the parasphenoid at the moment of the crushing (Fig. 3) . The little piece matched exactly with the rest of the two vomers.

The shapes of bones that lack well-preserved edges were reconstructed by referring to the preserved edges of surrounding bones. For example, the frontal (the left edge of the right frontal was covered by a portion of the left frontal; the left frontal permits to define the exact edges of the right frontal by complementarity), or the supratemporal (its exact shape is provided by the surrounding squamosal, postparietal, and tabular).

A brief, exploratory, landmark-based morphometric analysis (Bookstein, 1986) was conducted on 10 species of Amphibamidae (all amphibamids known except Gerobatrachus) in order to examine whether amphibamids could be discriminated by cranial morphology. Dorsal view reconstructions of each of the 10 amphibamid species were imported into TpsUtil (Rohlf, 2008b) . Landmarks, no more than 11 (number of species + 1) in order to not add uncertainty (Bookstein, 1991) , were digitized using Tps-Dig (Rohlf, 2008a) . Landmarks were selected on clearly identifiable points, such as suture junctions. Because our morphometric analysis is limited in the numbers of landmarks that can be used, different combinations of landmarks and baselines were used to analyze specific regions of the skull. Analysis was conducted with two different programs: different baselines were tested with Co-ordGen6h (Sheets, 2000; Fig. 6 ), and principal component analysis (PCA) and canonical variates were carried out using Morpho J (Klingenberg, 2008) .

The first analysis used a midline baseline and a total of 11 landmarks (Fig. 6A) . The principal component analysis found two groups, with the most significant difference in the skull being the enlargement of the skull, the increasing distance between the two orbits, and a narrowing of the midline length for the group of six dots. A plot of canonical variates (Fig. 7A ) finds two Figure 6 ; D, analysis of rostral portion of skull; E, analysis of otch notch shape. Black dots represent species from the "Amphibamus" clade; grey dots species from the "Micropholis" clade; open dot is Rubeostratilia. groups clearly defined: the first one with Tersomius, Micropholis, Pasawioops, and Rubeostratilia and the second one with Plemmyradytes, Platyrhinops, Georgenthalia, Amphibamus, Eoscopus, and Doleserpeton. These groupings mirror closely recent cladistic topologies, which also use some morphometric characters.

A second analysis focused on the length of the orbit and the otic notch and the distance between both (Fig. 6B) , and the baseline was placed on the posterior part of the skull. The results show two groups, visibly demonstrated with the canonical variates (Fig.  7B) , where the two groups are undoubtedly separated by a large gap. The deformation grid (Fig. 6B) shows that the major difference is located at the posterior part of the skull, with a shortening of the orbits and otic notch, and consequently the distance between both.

Another analysis was restricted to the postorbital region (Fig.  6C ). Like the two previous analyses, species clearly clustered into two groups (Fig. 7C ). These morphometric analyses support the result obtained from the character analysis, which finds two clades within amphibamids (see below).

An additional analysis focused on landmarks at the rostral section of the skull only, to test whether the observed clustering is due to a foreshortening of the preorbital region. Twelve landmarks were placed around the naris and the premaxilla (not shown). The results obtained were not significant, and no separation can be found in canonical variates (Fig. 7D) .

The final morphometric analysis was on variation in the morphology of the otic notch. The majority of landmarks were chosen around the otic notch and the lateral margin of the skull (not shown). There is some change in this area, and the canonical variates reveal the presence of the same two groups previously described (Fig. 7E) . Differing morphology seen between the two clades include a narrowing as well as the enlargement of the otic notch and the increasing gap between the ventral margin of the otic notch and the posterolateral extremity of the skull roof.

Since the original data matrix of amphibamids was assembled by Schoch and Rubidge (2005) , authors have added data from new six species: Plemmyradytes shintoni (Huttenlocker et al., 2007) , Georgenthalia clavinasica (Anderson et al., 2008a) , Pasawioops mayi (Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) , and Gerobatrachus hottoni (Anderson et al., 2008b) . Tersomius sp. was restricted to the specimen MCZ 1912 (Romer, 1947 Carroll, 1964; Anderson and Bolt, 2005) , following Schoch and Rubidge (2005) , Huttenlocker et al. (2007) , and Anderson et al. (2008a) . Finally, this new analysis includes the new species from Texas, Rubeostratilia. See Appendix 1.

We started the present analysis with the matrix from Fröbisch and Reisz's (2008) study, which is based on 62 cranial and postcranial characters and 18 temnospondyl taxa (Appendix 2). There are 17 ingroup taxa and Dendrerpeton acadianum, Sclerocephalus (no characters needed to be changed because of the publication of Schoch and Witzmann, 2009) , and Eryopidae were used as outgroups in order to polarize characters.

After examining the fossil material of Pasawioops, we disagree with the published coding (Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) of characters 48 (postfrontal shape) and 50 (pointed posterior projection on tabular) for this genus. Both were changed to state 1. Character number 16 (choana) was coded incorrectly for Gerobatrachus (Anderson et al., 2008b) and Georgenthalia , as was character 20 (narial flange) for Gerobatrachus. All were changed to state 1. Finally, character number 4 (parasphenoid dentition) cannot be observed in Gerobatrachus, so it was coded with a question mark.

After examining the material of Plemmyradytes at the Denver Science Museum, codings for characters 26 (supratympanic flange), 28 (semilunar flange), and 49 (otic notch to orbit) were changed for this taxon. Plemmyradytes, in our opinion, has a squamosal continuously ornamented around margin of otic notch (26:0), a supratemporal without ventral projection into otic notch (28:0), and an otic notch near the orbit (49:2). The effects of these three new codings upon topology will be examined in the following analyses.

Following Anderson et al. (2008a) , we added three characters to Fröbisch and Reisz's matrix (2008) We also added a new character related to the rostral margin of the prefrontal-lacrimal complex (Fig. 8) . The suture between these two bones and the nasal can be straight and continuous (state 0), or it can change direction abruptly, creating a posteriorly directed point along the rostral margin of the complex where the prefrontal meets the lacrimal (state 1). We coded this character as unknown for outgroup taxa because of greatly in-creased preorbital areas, and less interconnectivity between the prefrontal and lacrimal as a result. If we were to code this, most would have state 1, which would reverse the polarity within the ingroup, but doing so should not affect the analysis itself.

A parsimony analysis was performed using PAUP 4.0b10 (Swofford, 2001) and results subsequently examined using Mac-Clade 4.08 (Maddison and Maddison, 1992) . Characters were unordered, equally weighted, and were analyzed using the Branch and Bound algorithm. The robustness of nodes was assessed by calculating Bootstrap values (1000 bootstrap replicates; values are provided for nodes having values of greater than 50%).

In order to test the changed codings for three characters in Plemmyradytes, we will divide the analysis in two phases for subsequent discussion: the first analysis includes the changed code for Plemmyradytes (Fig. 9A) ; the second analysis uses the original coding (Fig. 9B) .

With Changed Coding for Plemmyradytes-The addition of the new characters and coding changes the pattern of amphibamid relationships (Fig. 9A) . Two trees are found with 147 steps, with the only difference of topology being in the arrangement of the outgroups Sclerocephalus and Eryopidea. Unlike most recent analyses (Schoch and Rubidge, 2005; Huttenlocker et al., 2007; Anderson et al., 2008a Anderson et al., , 2008b Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) , amphibamids in this analysis are arranged in a pectinate manner. Amphibamus, Gerobatrachus, and Doleserpeton group with a bootstrap value of 55%. This is supported by characters 9, 17, and 33:2. Then follow, in order from crown to stem, Platyrhinops, Eoscopus, and then a clade of Plemmyradytes and Georgenthalia. This seven-species clade is weakly supported; the bootstrap value is only 54%, and the clade is supported only by character 49:2. Note that no character groups Plemmyradytes and Georgenthalia other than reversions in characters 26 and 28. Subsequently the following clade is found (taxa in order from tip to root): Rubeostratilia, Pasawioops, Tersomius, and Micropholis most basally. The monophyly of Amphibamidae is very well supported with a bootstrap value of 97%, well supported by characters 14, 33:1, 34:2, 38, and 42. The clade of Dissorophoidea without Micromelerpeton is supported by characters 2, 20, 34:1, and 47, with a bootstrap value of 53%. The monophyly of Dissorophoidea is well supported with a bootstrap value of 99% and characters 1, 39:1, and 58. Note that the clade of Dissorophidae is well supported by bootstrap analysis (100%) and by characters 4, 39:2, and 46.

Rubeostratilia shares the ancestral state of characters 21 with Dendrerpeton, Sclerocephalus, and Eryopidae, and 52 with (((Amphibamus, Gerobatrachus) Doleserpeton) Platyrhinops). Those two characters are two differences between Pasawioops and the new specimen. Pasawioops and Micropholis share characters 54 and 7 with Tersomius as well but these two characters are not stronger enough to group those species together. Finally, Pasawioops, Micropholis, Rubeostratilia, and Amphibamus share character 5.

Following the methodology introduced by Anderson (2001), we searched these results for the effects of particular incomplete, and possibly 'wild card,' taxa (Table 1 ; Fig. 10) . When Plemmyradytes is deleted, we obtain one tree of 141 steps that restores the two clade structure within Amphibamidae: ((Micropholis, Tersomius) Pasawioops) Rubeostratilia) and (((((Amphibamus, Gerobatrachus) Doleserpeton) Georgenthalia) Platyrhinops) Eoscopus). We also achieve higher bootstrap values among Amphibamidae with this deletion. Amphibamus and Gerobatrachus cluster with 52%, with Doleserpeton the next taxon out, with 66% bootstrap support. Subsequent taxa placed sequentially stemward include Platyrhinops (55%) and Eoscopus and Georgenthalia (71%). We lack resolution for the rest of the group in the bootstrap tree, but we still find high bootstrap values for Amphibamidae (97%), Dissorophidae (100%), and Dissorophoidea (100%). When Rubeostratilia is deleted, we find the exact same relationships and bootstrap values among all Temnospondyli are as above.

Without Changes for Plemmyradytes-When we changed the three characters (26, 28, and 49) back to the original coding for Plemmyradytes, one tree of 146 steps is obtained, having the two-clade internal structure for Amphibamidae, and with Plemmyradytes sister taxa to Micropholis (Fig. 9B ). As usual, bootstrap values for this phylogeny are on the low side, but with good support for Dissorophoidea (99%), Dissorophidae (100%), Amphibamidae (97%), and the terminal trichotomy of Amphibamus, Gerobatrachus, and Doleserpeton (61%). The other main change is that Dissorophidae is not sister group to Amphibamidae anymore. We found them now closer to Ecolsonia and then Trematopidae within a monophyletic Olsoniformes (Anderson et al., 2008a) . This changes the interpretation of the evolution of some characters. Characters that previously supported the idea of grouping Dissorophidae and Amphibamidae together such as number 11, 12, and 15 appear twice. The number of total convergence increases in this topology, with 22 convergences (against 14 previously). With this other topology, it appear that characters 6 and 27:1 are characteristic of the taxon (((Amphibamus, Gerobatrachus) Doleserpeton) Georgenthalia), and characters 23:1, 34:1, 43:1, and 61:1 are apomorphies of the taxon (((Dissorophinae, Cacopinae) Ecolsonia) Trematopidae).
This underscores the need for carefully character definition and coding, because one or a few characters can produce substantial changes in tree shape (Anderson, 2001 ).

The morphometric analysis highlights several characters for each clade that can be summarized as below (Fig. 11) . The first group, composed of Tersomius, Pasawioops, Micropholis, and Rubeostratilia, is characterized by a long and narrow skull; orbits are situated far away from the otic notch, which is also very close to the edge of the skull roof (tabular). The second group, composed by Doleserpeton, Amphibamus, Platyrhinops, Plemmyradytes, Eoscopus, and Georgenthalia, is characterized by a broad skull with a shorter midline length; big orbits are closer to the otic notch; the distance between the tabular and the otic notch is more important in this group.

These results must be taken cautiously for the following reasons. (1) Data were taken from reconstructions and specimen drawings. The difference between the two kinds of drawing, perspective changes due to unremoved deformations, and extrapolation in the fabrication of reconstructions based on other taxa can be a source of not insignificant error. (2) The rostrum and the otic notch are probably the two most fragile parts of the skull and are less well preserved in the specimens. Most of the reconstructions show only a hypothetical interpretation. (3) The number of specimens is not great enough to be very confident in the conclusions; this is an exploratory survey and not one testing statistical FIGURE 11. Proportions of Amphibamus (Milner, 1982) , representative of the "Amphibamus" clade (left), compared to Rubeostratilia, representative of the " Micropholis" clade (right) . See text and Table 1 for more details. (Figure appears in color online.) significance. On the other hand, additional specimens would allow for the use of more landmarks, which might reveal currently unappreciated variation. (4) These features are often characteristic of ontogenetic changes (Clack and Milner, 2010) . However, these patterns are also consistent with the interpretation of evolution within the group via heterochronic processes (Fröbisch and Schoch, 2009) , a trend that began very early in dissorophoid history (Maddin et al., 2010) . Until more growth series are discovered, especially for the terminal clades, no more precise determination can be made.

The main differences between Pasawioops (Fröbisch and Reisz, 2008) and the new specimen from Texas are characters 13 (pterygoid-palatine) and 52 (alary process) (Fig. 12) . The alary process does not have the same extent between the two species regarding the projection size. If we draw a virtual line between the posterior borders of the two nares, we can see that the alary process is very close to this line in Pasawioops but more posterior in Rubeostratilia.

Observing Pasawioops, we can see a tiny, but clear, suture between the pterygoid and the palatine. Those two bones are clearly separate in the new specimen from Texas. This raises the following question: is it possible that the suture exists in the juvenile form and disappears during growth because bones become bigger and elongated leading the separation between pterygoidpalatine in the adult? Following Schoch (2002) , who was working on the ontogenetic evolution in temnospondyls, in particular Platyrhinops, there seems to have been no change in the suture between pterygoid-palatine; there was no suture in either the juvenile or adult of Platyrhinops. This therefore appears to be a reliable character to distinguish between Pasawioops and Rubeostratilia.

Both phylogenetic trees that we obtained ( Fig. 9 ; differing only in the coding of three characters for Plemmyradytes) strongly support the monophyly of Dissorophoidea with a bootstrap value of around 99% as well as the monophyly of Dissorophidae (100%) and Amphibamidae (around 97%), which is consistent with all recent articles.
body_text.section: Dissorophoid Relationships and Monophyly of Amphibamidae

body_text.text: Our analyses differ concerning the location of Micromelerpeton. The second set of results (with the original coding for Plemmyradytes; Fig. 9B ) places Micromelerpeton as sister group to Amphibamidae, followed by the Olsoniformes ; a clade containing Dissorophinae, Cacopinae, Ecolsonia, and Trematopidae). This result agrees with Anderson et al.'s (2008a Anderson et al.'s ( , 2008b analyses. Among Olsoniformes, our results show Dissorophidae and Trematopidae as sister groups, as also found in some recent articles (Huttenlocker et al., 2007; Anderson et al., 2008a Anderson et al., , 2008b . With our modification to the coding of Plemmyradytes (Fig. 9A ), Dissorophoidea assumes a pectinate shape, with Micromelerpeton in the most basal position, followed by Ecolsonia, Trematopidae, and then Dissorophidae as sister group to Amphibamidae. This result agrees with the analyses of Schoch and Rubidge (2005) and Fröbisch and Reisz (2008) .
body_text.section: Dissorophoid Relationships and Monophyly of Amphibamidae

body_text.text: There are no branchiosaurs in this analysis, which have been found deeply nested within Amphibamidae in recent analyses (Schoch and Milner, 2008; Fröbisch and Schoch, 2009) .
body_text.section: Dissorophoid Relationships and Monophyly of Amphibamidae

body_text.text: Unfortunately, Rubeostratilia is placed in different locations in the various analyses. The second analysis (without changed coding) shows two clades within amphibamids with the new specimen from Texas as most basal in the clade with Micropholis. On the other hand, the first analysis shows a pectinate amphibamid tree. The new species is placed in the middle of this tree, appearing just after Micropholis, Tersomius, and Pasawioops and before all the rest of amphibamids. Regardless, a close association exists between Rubeostratilia and these other amphibamids.

In present study we see the importance of individual character coding. By changing three characters from missing data to definitive states, one can change completely the tree topology, and by extension the pattern of evolution of amphibamids. Do we have two independent clades or pectinate branching among amphibamids? This study shows that we obtain different results each time that we add/delete a character or a taxon, so the utmost care must be taken in character description and coding. Additional work remains to be done to discover new characters in order to resolve these relationships.

Plemmyradytes is truly unstable-placed one time with Doleserpeton and the rest of the time with Micropholis, which suggests that additional work is required to better characterize this species. The dramatic change in the phylogeny with changing just three states for this species proves the importance of each character in the matrix. When we calculate the percentage of missing data for each species (Fig. 10) , the highest value is Plemmyradytes with 45% question marks. Second in the list is Georgenthalia, with 33% missing data. Additional specimens (which apparently exist for Plemmyradytes; Huttenlocker, pers. comm. to J.S.A., 2008) will undoubtedly stabilize the pattern of relationships.

This study presents a new species found in the Early Permian of Texas. It is a new amphibamid temnospondyl, characterized by well-known features, such as the laterally exposed palatine, the dorsal quadrate process and the narial flange characteristic of Dissorophoidea, and the presence of palpebral ossification characteristic of Amphibamidae. Unfortunately, the large amount of missing data in the matrix creates some instability, and new characters did not resolve the relationships. A brief morphometric analysis supports the presence of two groups of amphibamids based on a shortening of the postorbital skull table and expansion of the orbits and otic notch, consistent with paedomorphosis.

In the future, new species and characters should better define amphibamid relationships. It will be interesting to test recent suggestions that Branchiosauridae is deeply nested within Amphibamidae (Schoch and Milner, 2008; Fröbisch and Schoch, 2009) . Smaller-scale anatomical features, such as the palpebral complex or the construction of the otic notch, may provide additional characters. The idea that the two clades of amphibamids are adapted to different ecologies could be tested by studying the postcranial skeleton; differences in locomotion should be reflected in different construction of the vertebrae, the placement of muscular insertions, and the bone microstructure. Finally, more thorough knowledge of amphibamid phylogeny should help better understand instances of miniaturization or paedomorphosis, important evolutionary factors that can potentially confound phylogenetic relationships. APPENDIX 1. Character list. Characters 1-62 were taken from Fröbisch and Reisz (2008) . Sources for additional characters given below.

(1) Laterally exposed palatine. (0) Palatine overplated by jugal and lacrimal with no dorsal exposure; (1) Palatine wedging between lacrimal and jugal to make contribution to skull roof an orbital margin. (1) Pterygoid contacting only ectopterygoid, or, when latter absent, maxilla. (14) Palatine, ectopterygoid. (0) Palatine and ectopterygoid much wider than maxilla; (1) Palatine and ectopterygoid reduced to narrow struts not wider than adjoining maxilla. (15) Interpterygoid vacuity. (0) Interpterygoid vacuity roundish or oval in outline; (1) Interpterygoid vacuity greatly expanded laterally at midlevel. (16) Choana. (0) Choana narrow, forming elongate oval with parallel, parasagittal lateral and medial margins; (1) Choana expanded anteromedially. (17) Pedicely. (0) Adult dentition of marginal jaw and palatal elements consisting of conical, fully mineralized teeth;

(1) Jaw and/or palatal teeth-in larger, presumably adult stage-subdivided by unmineralised zone forming separate tooth crown. (18) Bicuspidity. (0) Larval and adult teeth conical or needle shaped with single tip (monocuspid); (1) Jaw and/or palatal teeth-in larger, presumably adult stage-bicuspid. (2) Pleurocentra fused ventrally to form large element that has become main bearer of vertebral column, intercentra much smaller than in plesiomorphic condition. (34) Rib length. (0) Moderately elongate thoracic ribs in adult stage, may or may not bear uncinate processes and usually curved distoventrally; (1) Thoracic ribs without distal curvature, but may ear uncinate processes;
(2) Thoracic ribs very short, simple rods.

FIGREF11.text: (2) Dorsal quadrate process. (0) Quadrate having smooth posterodorsal side in plesiomorphic state;(1)  Quadrate with prominent dorsoposterior outgrowth, the quadrate process.(3) Vomerine depression. (0) Ventral surface of vomers flat and element divided into anterior and posterior portion by transverse ridges that may or may not bear transverse tooth row; (1) Single unpaired depression in anterior portion of vomers that may or may not house an opening (4) Parasphenoid dentition. (0) Basal plate of parasphenoid bearing shagreen of small teeth (denticles) anteromedially;(1) Plate entirely smooth.(5) Parasphenoid denticle field. (0) Parasphenoid denticle field well established, with triangular outline and with apex reaching onto base of cultriform process; (1) Denticle field greatly expanded anteriorly to cover most of the cultriform process. (6) Parasphenoid basal plate. (0) Basal plate roughly quadrangular, as long as wide; (1) Basal plate much shorter than wide, reaching about half the width. (7) Vomerine denticle field. (0) Vomer covered with more or less dense shagreen of teeth in addition to obligatory fang pair; (1) Shagreen confined to juvenile stages and/or absent throughout ontogeny. (8) Vomerine fangs. (0) Vomer lacking fangs in its medial portion, outside lateral tooth arcade, but have smaller accessory teeth in that region; (1) Vomer with additional fang pairs posterior to mid-vomerine depression. (9) Palatine fangs. (0) Palatine with one fang pair in its anterior third; (1) Palatine fangs replaced by patch of small, equally sized teeth. (10) Ectopterygoid fangs. (0) Ectopterygoid with one fang pair at about midlevel; (1) Ectopterygoid without fangs. (11) Pterygoid-vomer. (0) Retention of suture between pterygoid (palatine ramus) and vomer; (1) Pterygoid contacting only posterior-most portion of palatine and lacking suture with vomer. (12) Pterygoid flange. (0) Palatine ramus of pterygoid merging continuously into basioterygoid ramus; (1) Palatine ramus broadening abruptly to form transverse flange. (13) Pterygoid-palatine. (0) Pterygoid (palatine ramus) reaching and suturing to palatine;

FIGREF12.text: Labyrinthodonty. (0) Jaw and palatal teeth labyrinthodont at least in adult stages; (1) These teeth never labyrinthodont at any stage of development. (20) Narial flange. (0) Ventral (inner) side of prefrontal, lacrimal, and nasal smooth; (1) Inner side of these bones forming complicated bar-like structure (narial flange), permitting contact with antorbital bar. (21) Prefrontal process (0) Prefrontal forming simple suture with lacrimal laterally; (1) Prefrontal underplating lacrimal widely by means of ventral prefrontal process contacting palatine. (22) Tabular size. (0) Tabular narrower than postparietal, but reaching almost same size as latter; (1) Tabular minute and laterally constricted by unique enlargement of otic notch. (23) Tabular-squamosal. (0) Tabular and squamosal widely separated by supratemporal; (1) Squamosal meeting tabular, excluding supratemporal from otic notch. (24) Postparietal length. (0) Postparietal forming transversely rectangular or quadrangular element; (1) Postparietal abbreviated and reduced to narrow, poorly ornamented strut at posterior margin of skull table. (25) Squamosal-supratemporal. (0) Suture between squamosal and supratemporal nearly as long as supratemporal itself; (1) Foreshortened squamoso-supratemporal suture reaching only one-third or less length of supratemporal. (26) Supratympanic flange (= semilunar flange in Schoch and Rubidge, 2005, terminology following Bolt (1974)). (0) Squamosal continuously ornamented around margin of otic notch; (1) Squamosal having dorsally exposed and ornamented area (supratympanic flange) stepping abruptly into steeply aligned, poorly ornamented portion. (27) Supratemporal length. (0) Supratemporal and parietal elongated, having similar length, reaching more than double the length of all other bone in posterior skull table; (1) These elements posteriorly abbreviated, supratemporal markedly shorter than parietal. (28) Semilunar flange (= supratemporal flange of Schoch and Rubidge, 2005). (0) Supratemporal without ventral projection into otic notch; (1) Supratemporal forming marked ventral flange participating in medial bordering of otic notch. (29) Prefrontal-postfrontal. (0) Prefrontal and postfrontal firmly sutured, excluding the frontal form orbital margin; (1) Both elements separated by frontal, at least dorsally. (30) Skull width. (0) Moderately wide skull with jugals, postorbitals, and medial skull roofing series usually longer than wide; (1) Skull table and cheek overall broadened, most elements being as wide as long or wider. (31) Palpebral ossifications. (0) Ossifications in orbit restricted to sclerotic ring; (1) Numerous palpebral ossicles at medial margin of sclerotic ring. (32) Stapes. (0) Stapes with pronounced dorsodistal curvature directed towards dorsally located otic notch; (1) Stapes abbreviated without dorsodistal curvature, directed laterally towards vertically aligned otic notch. (33) Pleurocentra. (0) Temnospondyl pleurocentra primitively paired, dorsally separated elements failing to reach ventral level of adjunct intercentrum (classical rhachitomous condition); (1) Pleurocentra approaching each other on ventral side;
